posts.name: Carl Hauser
posts.cooked:
We saw our autos at competition pause briefly about 1.5 seconds into the auto. We eventually determined that this was correlated with a scheduler loop overrun (40-100ms) occurring in our SwerveSubsystem.periodic() method. From the timing we suspected that it occurred when the the cameras first identified an Apriltag. We subsequently confirmed this at home: with the robot sitting idle after restarting robot code, revealing an Apriltag in the camera field of view causes a loop overrun in SwerveSubsystem.periodic(). Subsequently hiding and revealing the Apriltag does not cause further occurrences.

The code of SwerveSubsystem.periodic() is

visionDriveTest is true .

We have subsequently added timing measurements between each of the statements in this code and determined that the big time-takers are one of the CameraSubsystem.getGlobalPoseFrom*(); (Whichever sees the tag first). and the call to swerveDrive.addVisionMeasurement which is just a wrapper for WPILib’s PoseEstimator.addVisionMeasurement. The CameraSubsystem.getGlobalPoseFrom*(); methods look like:

where it appears the line result = m_photonPoseEstimatorLeft.update(m_LeftCam.getLatestResult()); is the likely culprit. But why this would take a long time on the first result that actually sees a tag and not later ones is a mystery.

Does anybody have any insight as to what is happening here? or what to do to fix or mitigate it?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
chauser:

autos at competition pause briefly about 1.5 seconds into the auto

Ours did too but our fix might not apply to you. Turns out we had coded the WPILib PoseEstimator and CTRE generated swerve drive had one, too, that was being used. We removed the redundant WPILib pose estimator and no longer have the significant pause in auto.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: What PoseStrategy are you using for the PhotonPoseEstimators?

posts.name: Carl Hauser
posts.cooked:
The primary strategy is MULTI_TAG_PNP_ON_COPROCESSOR and the fallback  is LOWEST_AMBIGUITY .

Regardless of the strategy there is only a single tag in view of the camera when this happens.

posts.name: Carl Hauser
posts.cooked: Thanks. I dont think that’s directly it – we have only one WPILib pose estimator – but it is interesting that having two could cause the same symptom. Something to keep in mind as we dig in further.

posts.name: guineawheek
posts.cooked: We’ve been having similar issues as well and we suspect the issue relates to how Java classes are lazy-loaded; the first time code paths get run on robot restart, Java needs to actually load the classes in and run them. We’ve been waving apriltags in front of our robot before setting it on the starting position in matches for this reason

posts.name: Carl Hauser
posts.cooked:
Delayed code loading was one of the hypotheses that we were considering and trying to figure out how to test.

We had thought about “wave a tag” as a mitigation and have resisted out of concern that showing the wrong tag would cause the robot to believe it was in the wrong place on the field, potentially causing it to do something highly inappropriate for the real location once enabled. Do you have a code solution for this or are you just really careful about what tag you show?

One thing I’m thinking of trying tomorrow is generating a dummy, but valid (not quite sure what that entails) PhotonPipeLineResult and feeding it to the PhotonPoseEstimators immediately after they are constructed. That should force any code loading that needs to happen. By not ever passing the results to the WPILib PoseEstimator I think that the robot will not be confused about its location. Oh ho! That suggests that it may be ok if we don’t feed the PhotonPoseEstimator results to the WPILib PoseEstimator when the robot is disabled – that would be easy to accomplish.

posts.name: guineawheek
posts.cooked:
chauser:

We had thought about “wave a tag” as a mitigation and have resisted out of concern that showing the wrong tag would cause the robot to believe it was in the wrong place on the field, potentially causing it to do something highly inappropriate for the real location once enabled. Do you have a code solution for this or are you just really careful about what tag you show?

We run the pipeline in disabled and tell the robot exactly where it should be when auto starts from lineup. Localization is allowed to be a foot or so off in our case because our auto-align does the final approach to the tags anyway

chauser:

We had thought about “wave a tag” as a mitigation and have resisted out of concern that showing the wrong tag would cause the robot to believe it was in the wrong place on the field, potentially causing it to do something highly inappropriate for the real location once enabled. Do you have a code solution for this or are you just really careful about what tag you show?

You could also try positioning your robot in a way that the cameras see one of the field AprilTags.

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
pigrammer:

You could also try positioning your robot in a way that the cameras see one of the field AprilTags.

Just want to confirm this worked for us. You can see the delay when it first sees the tag but it’s happening during disabled so it doesn’t matter. So long as the entire code path is being run it will initialize everything.

You can still set the position at auto start if you want.

posts.name: Carl Hauser
posts.cooked: I Just found this: 4+ Second loop overrun when seeing a tag for the first time · Issue #1792 · PhotonVision/photonvision · GitHub – looks like the same thing, but the symptom is way worse (4 seconds vs 100ms).
